thread.title: Hard time in Southie
thread.title_full: Hard time in Southie | Boston Herald

author: Dan Ventura
title: Hard time in Southie
text:
Football is a numbers game and no one knows that any better than South Boston coach Ray Butler.
For the second time in three weeks, Butler had to address his beleaguered troops to tell them that they were forfeiting a game. The loss to Boston English dropped the Knights to 0-6 on the season heading into the Burke game this week.
“We’ve had so many injuries of late that we were down to 11 players,” Butler said. “We’ve had two ACL injuries, a broken hand and five concussions. We thought we were going to get some players back, but they didn’t get the clearance, so I called the Boston English coach (Joe Cain) and (athletic director) Avery Esdaile Thursday night to tell them we had to forfeit.
“The kids want to play, but we want to do the right thing by them. We’re hoping to get some kids back this week so that we can play a game.”
Adding to the problem is the fact South Boston is trying to compete with several underclassmen playing key roles. The spirit is clearly willing, but that can only take you so far in football.
“We have 13- and 14-year-old kids who have never played before going up against 18-year-olds,” Butler said. “They’re trying to get better, they want to get better, but they’re physically not ready.”
The long range hope is that South Boston can keep enough players healthy to field a team to play on Thanksgiving against longtime rival East Boston. Jets coach John Parziale expressed hope that the 98th meeting between the schools would happen.
“We’ve been pretty focused on our own schedule, but we’ve noticed the forfeits,” Parziale said. “We hope that they can get their kids healthy in the next month. It’s always been a big game for the two schools.”
Butler vowed that he would do anything possible to field a roster on Thanksgiving, regardless of how many players would be able to dress.
“My first year, we dressed 14 kids against them and played the game,” Butler said. “If the (Boston English) game was on Thanksgiving, I think we would have tried to play because there is no tomorrow.”
Sweet 16
(Last week’s rankings in parantheses)
1. (1) XAVERIAN (6-0): Hawks defensive backs are like sharks smelling blood every time the ball is in the air.
2. (2) ST. JOHN’S PREP (6-0): Dodged a major bullet against BC High Friday night.
3. (3) MARSHFIELD (6-0): The run to another Atlantic Coast League title was a bit anticlimactic for the talented Rams.
4. (4) NORTH ATTLEBORO (6-0): Every week, a different kid steps to the forefront.
5. (5) HOLLISTON (6-0): Panthers too much for Medway en route to the Tri-Valley Large title.
6. (6) DUXBURY (5-1): Win over Silver Lake was tempered by the season-ending loss of standout wide receiver Ryan Reagan to a leg injury.
7. (7) CENTRAL CATHOLIC (5-1): Raiders have won 19 straight against Merrimack Valley Conference competition.
8. (8) READING (5-1): Would love nothing better than to settle some scores against Arlington.
9. (9) TEWKSBURY (5-1): One-two punch of Troy Carey and Adam Gajjaoui proved to be lethal to Chelmsford.
10. (14) BILLERICA (6-0): Maybe it’s time for some local entrepreneur to create a “We Dig Sigs” bumper sticker.
11. (12) MILTON (6-0): Take care of business against Dedham to set up a winner-take-all showdown with Wellesley for the Bay State Herget title.
12. (13) MELROSE (6-0): Unsung quarterback Julian Nyland had another big effort.
13. (15) EVERETT (3-3): The youth movement may be under way in Everett.
14. (11) BC HIGH (4-2): Showed some moxie in rallying to take St. John’s Prep to overtime before succumbing.
15. (16) EAST BRIDGEWATER (6-0): Impressive showing in handing Dighton-Rehoboth its first loss.
16. (NR) WELLESLEY (6-0): We vow never to refer to this team as the Red Raiders again.
